Posts.Content: Going on my experience, I went to the breast clinic as I found a lump I had a physical examination and the area where the lump was, was marked I then was sent straight for a mammogram and then into an ultra sound.  I was told there and then it was cancer.  A biopsy was taken and they also examined the lamp nodes under the arm.  I had my husband with me, which was a great because he listened out for things he knew I wouldn't.  I was asked if I had discharge from the nipple and also wether I had any numbness in my arm.  Its good your mum is going with you.  I went to the doctors with my lump and was told not to worry as it was tissue damage, so husband and I went together on the proviso after the examination we were going out to lunch.  So you can imagine the shock I had laying on the bed to be told its Breast Cancer.  We still haven't been out to lunch and its ten months on.   Please use this site, everyone on here is wonderful everyone has been through it.  The advise, love and hugs is unbelievable.  Any questions everyone has answers because they probably have been through it.
Posts.Title: First appointment Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi, I found a lump in breast last April went to the doctors who told me it was tissue damage but go and have a mammogram to check. Had mammogram and lump detected and then ultrasound straight after, told there and then before biopsy taken it was cancer.  Will never forget the lady doing the ultra sound asked how I felt and I thought how do you think I feel, but my husband who was there said I swore at her so he jumped in to say you have to understand the doctor told her it was tissue damage.  Them told they would do a biopsy then but would have to come back a week later for results.  Day after laying to rest his aunt who died of breast cancer had it confirmed by doctor it was.  Doctor surprised that husband and I were so calm but explained what was said and that we had weekend to come to terms with it.  It is the most mind numbing thing to here that word, please keep on this site women and men are wonderful you get advice  and even reading through other peoples comments we are all in this together.  My thought are with you, fingers crossed xx
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi, due to reaction of FEC and vein problems I had a port (I think that's what it was called) put in.  It was inserted above the right book which was the good one, as the other was reconstructed.  Yes it felt weird but they would that to put the FEC and T through I had no line coming out at all.  Are you able to ask about that option?
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: Inspiring, wonderful and so true.  Well done on reaching the end of your chemo trip xx
Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi,  I had reconstruction using my stomach last May.  After twelve weeks I was checked for healing and to see if the hips had devils horns.  Apparently two pointed floppy skin areas, this I was told can be cut off with further surgery.  I was very lucky and didn't need that done as I healed okay.  At the start of my treatment the surgeon looked at top and bottom of buttocks for fat, top of thighs, back area and last of all the tummy.
Posts.Title: stage 2 of diep

Posts.Content: Getting that diagnosis is the worst thing, however in this site you have wonderful people that have been or are going through the same as you.  They have advice, tips and to actually know you are talking to people who now how you are feeling is reassuring.  i have finished my treatment and find every twitch or ache I get I think its come back.  Keep coming back to this site like I do there will be lots of answers and caring people.  Sending you a hug x
Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: Hello, after just having a mastectomy and reconstruction myself are you saying secondary tumours occur after this procedure?  Sorry confused by what you wrote
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: Hello, after just having a mastectomy and reconstruction myself are you saying secondary tumours occur after this procedure?  Sorry confused by what you wrote
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: I can only tell you of my experience, as everyone is different.  I was diagnosed last April with a lump in the left breast I have a biopsy before and as nothing was found went straight in for a mastectomy and reconstruction.  During the op they took four nodes out and two were found to have slight traces in, so chemo was recommended as a precautionary.  Following chemo recommendation was I have all nodes taken out which I was all for.  Operation was in December last year and was in hospital one night.  Saw physio for arm exercises who explained they MUST be done every day.  When I went back to my doctor four weeks later I was able to raise arm over my head, had 80ml drained off which apparently was very good as it can be more.  Second appointment two weeks later another 20ml drained off.  I asked about wearing a sleeve as I had done a lot of research but was advised not to as they like to see how you get on.  After operation I was advised a further two nodes showed slight traces so they said removal of nodes was right decision for me.  I have since have fifteen sessions of radiotherapy as well.  Like you I am religious about my arm exercises, also joined a local Pilates group which has helped also. I read a lot about lymphedema and yes it does scare me, but like you I am religious about my arm exercises, and so far so good.
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Hello, I can only tell you of my experience. I was diagnosed last April had a biopsy done at start and told no signs in the nodes so straight for mastectomy and reconstruction.  Four nodes taken out during op and two showed slight traces so chemo then recommended as a precautionary. After chemo, recommended all nodes taken out under arm in hospital for one night and the remainder taken out.  Even after chemo a further two showed slight traces, so that was four out of the twenty ish under the arm.  Operation was five weeks after last chemo,  I have been doing exercises as shown by physio.  Had two appointments since op, 80ml of fluid drained off first time which apparently was good and a tiny amount drained second time. Have been very lucky in recovery.  I start three weeks of radiotherapy tomorrow., which works out to approximately seven weeks after op. Everyone is different in healing and recovery.  They will want you to be able to raise your arm above your head before radiotherapy.  Being told this geared me to doing exercises.
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Had my eyes tested last Tuesday, which is four months pre chemo.  My optician aware of my treatment so gave me a thorough examination took photographs also and I have been very lucky my eye sight hasn't been effected.  I was asked if my eyes were dry during chemo but I didn't notice any difference.
Posts.Title: Eyesight after treatment ?

Posts.Content: Hi. I'm 47 and got diagnosed grade two in April this year. I was originally told by my doctor it was tissue damage so imagine my surprise when hospital said its BC.  I have a fourteen your old daughter and was honest with her from the start, however what I did say to her laying on the bed was I'm not going anywhere I have your sixteenth, eighteenth, prom, twenty first, marriage to see and I also want to be a nanny.  I got through setting myself targets and trying to be positive about it, which believe me isn't easy.  My first target was to get up with my daughter and husband everyday, if I went back to bed after they had gone to work and school that was fine.  I had down days but my family where a reason to keep going and fighting.  My daughter is older I know but my husband and I were honest with her from the start and she has said she likes that.  Does MacMillan have books that you could purchase for telling your daughters in a way they understand? I have found this site to be great with people putting their stories on here, and believe me we have all been through or are going through our journeys and I couldn't think of a better way to get advise but from people who have been there.
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Please don't panic you've done exactly what I did.  As soon as I got told Tamoxifen I looked it up on line.  As people have said everyone is different, people have been having Tamoxifen for years and not had any side effects.  It was the doctor who said to me when I mentioned what I had read on line, people are always quick to write the problems they have had you very very rarely read about people who are happy with what they are on and how good it has been.  If you have any concerns whilst on it I totally agree go back to the doctors, my doctor also said the same to me always come back we can give you something to counteract effects, if you get any
Posts.Title: Tablets

Posts.Content: Hello Like others I can only tell of my experience, as everyone is different.  I had three Fec and three T and did suffer with my mouth.  Once bit of advise that I was given before my chemo was have ice pops in the freezer and suck on one of those.  They were brilliant for me.  Cursedly I used also, but was advised by my Oncologist to water it down a bit.  Frozen grapes were great also, wash them put them in a tupperware dish in the freezer and just dip into them.  They were cold in the mouth but made if feel refreshed.  I have recently finished treatment and feel my mouth and taste buds aren't back to pre treatment yet.
Posts.Title: Sore mouth

Posts.Content: This site is brilliant I was diagnosed last April, have had mastectomy reconstruction, chemo, removal of all nodes, about to start the second week of Radiotherapy.  Everyone seems to be on different tablets for the BC I am on Tamoxifen, is it rude to ask what the difference is between them all.  I know I could look it all up on line but here people actually taking them can tell me. Thank you everyone.
Posts.Title: Tablets

Posts.Content: Please don't let your mum make you feel guilty, I had exactly the same with my mum.  Mum was diagnosed with cancer just before me, then I followed last March.  I had a mastectomy and reconstruction but mum couldn't understand why I couldn't come and visit her even though I had explained I couldn't drive for eight to ten weeks I was heavily bandaged midriff and breast and could only shuffle walk for the first four weeks.  I know its selfish but you have to think about yourself now, like me you will have to go through all the treatment and you have to recover at your own speed.  When my mum did visit she said she felt more sorry for my sister as she must be worried about if she was going to get it next.  No discussion on how I was, how I was finding the treatment.  I found phoning was the answer you can talk over the phone.  Good luck keep smiling xx Always remember you are braver thank you believe, stronger than you seem and smarter than you think
Posts.Title: Feeling helpless and guilty

Posts.Content: I agree just because the letter says you should be fit doesn't mean you should be.  We have all been on a very long journey, mine started last May and I start radiotherapy on Monday.  I was told I could have gone back to work after chemo, I work in a school, but I chose to stay away until everything has finished.  My doctor has given me sick certificates and has said only go back when you feel right.  Remember listen to your body, you are the important one now.
Posts.Title: Help ......

Posts.Content: Hello I wondered if anyone could advise me please.  I am six months past FEC-T chemo for Breast Cancer and have tried to colour my hair.  I have always wanted to go pink and as my hair is short have tried with little success.  The dye was done at a hairdressers and I said I wanted a temporary one that would wash out after a couple of weeks well it went after a week.  I have last night put another one on, LIVE purple.  This is also starting to come out, should I go straight to permanent colour.  Any suggestions would be great I am able to cover all body scars but so wish to change my grey hair so I can feel a bit normal Thank you
Posts.Title: Colouring Hair

Posts.Content: Well done on reaching the end.  I was also on FEC-T and like you I struggled walking up the stairs.  When I saw my oncologist he said it was water retention and would go in a couple of weeks.  I was advised to try and keep moving as apparently that would swoosh the water around the body and it would come out.
Posts.Title: Chemo done!

Posts.Content: Good Luck!!! I know what you mean I recently had mine in May due to weight loss through Slimming World my reconstructed breast had change shape so after a scan had to have that one mammogram along with other breast.  Then had to have another scan as he could see something but was told it was an old blood vessel linked to one of the new ones.  Left there being told come back in six months but then get a phone call could I go back and have a further scan.  Appointment next Wednesday so panicking myself about that.  You try and get on with life as best you can but its always there to pop up isn't it.
Posts.Title: 2 yearly mammogram tomorroe

Posts.Content: Hi, I had mastectomy and reconstruction last May followed by Chemo which finished November, nodes out December and start Radiotherapy 1st February.  It is right, you are taken to room before op where they connect you up and put medication through and also its right my conversation was about the Eurovision Song Contest and who had won, the next thing I knew I was awake in recovery.  I was connected to Morphine machine which I could control myself if in pain, and was regularly asked if I wanted any other pain killers.  The new boob was covered but everyday the nurse came in and scanned it to check everything okay.  I was very very tired, because yes it does take a lot out of your body.  The one thing I struggled with was the heat in the room, I suffer anyway in the heat I swell up.  I would recommend taking a couple of flannels in with you and ask for them to be put under cold water and then you can put them on your forehead I found this helped me.  Remember everyone is different in how they handle pain.   Before I had mine I was petrified, now I just look back and think of the journey I have been on and still am.  It will go well, listen to your body and remember you are stronger than you think!!
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy and recon on Thursday sacred!!!!
